resources.string:
The following networking/data access architecture is used in this sample app: 

Retrofit with RxJava for the REST API calls, and EventBus to deliver the results back to the presentation layer. 
Rx features to handle errors, multiple calls, fallback to offline store, and more. 
The whole component is placed in a Android Service which starts on-demand and stops after a timeout when there are no more ongoing tasks. 

More info at each use-case. 

Tip: Switch between real and mocked weather service in menu.

User initiates data access, receives the result on UI. Requires a single network call. 
 
 - Displays loading indicator 
 - Handles rotation (keeps indicator, doesn't restart call) 
 - Can deliver result to different screen

Retrofit with RxJava for the API call, and EventBus to deliver the results back to the presentation layer. \nThe whole component is put in an Android Service which starts on-demand and stops when there is no more ongoing task.
Get the 5 day forecast for the city that is warmer currently
No internet connection and no offline data
Error message displayed if something went wrong. \nDifferent messages for different errors.
1. Use Real Weather Service (invalid API key used here -> error dialog) \n2. Disconnect from internet (no internet error message) \n3. Use Mock Weather service (completes successfully)
Errors propagate through the Rx chain and interpreted at single place at the end. Error event is sent to presentation layer where message is decided.
API key unauthorized\n(A custom user message could come here)
There is only one call running at a time, initiating again is ignored.
Rx Subscription reference is kept and checked if subscribed.
Use Mock service (real one is too fast) and tap the button multiple times. Try basic use-case for comparison.
When online, network call is executed and result is displayed and saved. \nWhen offline, data is loaded from offline store.
Rx operators doOnSuccess and onErrorResumeNext are used to construct the appropriate chain.
Go offline and tap the button. \nClearing the saved data is available in the menu.

User initiates data access, receives the result on UI. Requires a single network call. 

 - Progress dialog 
 - Error handling 
 - Offline store 
 - Ongoing call handling 
 - Retry

User initiates data access, receives the result on UI. 
Requires multiple network calls. Both parallel and sequential executions are needed. 

Shows dialog about the progress steps.
Rx operator zip for parallel execution and flatMap for sequential execution. \nProgress update events sent to presentation layer at any point in Rx chain.
Retries the call multiple times if it fails.
- Try with no connection (retries and fails with no internet message) \n- Try with real service (retries and fails with invalid api key message) \n- Try with mock service (succeeds)
User can cancel the ongoing network call.
Retrofit supports cancelling the call down to the network layer through the returned Observable/Single\'s unsubscribe() method.

To be able to cancel during the very fast network call, tapping the button initiates the call and the cancel as well right away in the next looper round. \nCheck the code and the logs to see that the call does not complete.
Real: api.openweathermap.org \n\nMock: Retrofit annotated interface mocked. Returns random value after 3-4 seconds.
Syncing the current temperature with exponential backoff
Scheduled background data sync with server. \nEven if app is not running/used by the user.

The Service used for on-demand data access can be started up for syncing too. \nScheduling here is done simply with AlarmManager. (JobScheduler or GcmNetworkManager is a better solution in a real app) \nSynced data is available in offline store.
Start syncing with the button, stop it with X. \nUse mock service to see the values changing.
If offline data is available, show that first but load from server too and refresh the value. Execute them in parallel.
Combining the two Rx Observables with operator concatEager.
Use with mock server (real one is too fast).
